content.description: Tech up the vertical face to a great stance before the overhang. Charge up the 5.12- steep face on pumping edges to a heartbreaker crux before the last bolt. Embrace the heinous for a move or two then recollect yourself on some iron jugs before navigating to the anchor.
content.location: Smack dab in between Pinkalicious and 72 Hour Energy.

climbs.name: Wild Turkey Crossing
climbs.fa: Clifton Gifford, Eric Jones, Isaac McShane, 2013

content.description: Start up Golden Snow Cone to reach the large left leaning flake. Follow this large flake up and left with good laybacking and jamming. Try not to piss off climbers on the sport routes intersecting this obvious plumb line. Finish on the anchors of Pinkalicious.
content.protection: Small rack of hand-sized gear, plus draws/alpines to clip some bolts along the way
content.location: Follows the large flake that trends up and left from Golden Snow Cone through 72-Hour Energy, Zero Dark Fiddy, and Pinkalicious.

content.description: Flow through good jugs at the beginning until the pocket band. Stab through good pockets and keep moving until your feet are above the band, then regroup and continue to the chains.
content.location:
To access the right side of the Bear's Den, branch right off the main trail to a lesser-traveled logging road down into the drainage then back up to the other side. The trail spits you out at "Cut Tree Wall" which hosts three lines currently. The "Twelve Wall" is to the left and "Project Wall" further to the right.

This route and its neighbor climb the shotgun-pocketed wall at the far right of the entire crag. "Ursa Minor" is on the left, "Ursa Major" on the right.

content.description: Similar to its counterpart, climb a friendlier start to a punchy band of pockets. Dirtier the higher you get and a moss-covered flake to clip chains. The lesser of the twin lines, also felt similar in difficulty.
content.location:
To access the right side of the Bear's Den, branch right off the main trail to a lesser-traveled logging road down into the drainage then back up to the other side. The trail spits you out at "Cut Tree Wall" which hosts three lines currently. The "Twelve Wall" is to the left and "Project Wall" further to the right.

This route and its neighbor climb the shotgun-pocketed wall at the far right of the entire crag. "Ursa Minor" is on the left, "Ursa Major" on the right.

climbs.name: Two Rons Don't Make a Right

content.description: Climb the blunt arête making thoughtful, delicate moves on directional pockets. Rest in a massive hueco about two-thirds of the way up then continue to the top.
content.protection:
8 bolts to anchors.

Currently only two offset bolts with a carabiner each at the top.
content.location:
To access the right side of the Bear's Den, branch right off the main trail to a lesser-traveled logging road down into the drainage then back up to the other side. The trail spits you out at "Cut Tree Wall" which hosts three lines currently. The "Twelve Wall" is to the left and "Project Wall" further to the right.

This follows the obvious blunt arête up the farthest right line of the "Twelve Wall"

content.description: Climb the face on mostly good holds with the occasional long pull until you reach the break in the wall. Make a couple tough moves to gain an edge where you can eye the upcoming crux which involves a small right hand pocket. Climb to the top on positive holds and big moves.
content.location: On the Twelve Wall on the right side of Bear's Den, this climb is the third route from the left, located just to the right of the popular Bear Belly.

content.description: Farthest route to the left at the Bears Den. Climb up on to a small ledge below the first bolt then work up the awkward crack and then right on good holds.
content.location: Farthest left route at the Bears Den. After taking the split to the Bears Den this is the first fork on the left. The route is where the spit hits the cliff.

content.description: Begin near a head height hueco on chossy holds. A number of boulder problems separated by good rests await.
content.location: Begins in the hueco at head height.

climbs.name: Squatter
climbs.fa: Mike Anderson, Janelle Anderson, Shaun Corpron - 2010

content.description:
This route starts with some ledges and moves up through excellent climbing with decent rests to a tough anchor clip. This route can serve as a nice warm-up for the harder routes at the Bear's Den or for the Lode.

We back-cleaned the first draw (shared bolt with Mooch) which helped with rope drag; certainly not mandatory though.
content.location: Second route from the right side of the "Steep Wall" area. Just left of Mooch (shares the first bolt).

content.description: Technical, crimpy climbing on a slightly overhanging arete. With the difficult to find rests adding to the pump, this one is a truly tough onsight! If everyone brought a brush, this amazing line would clean up in a handful of ascents.
content.location: Dive down the trail on your right near the center of the crag, coming from the main trail head, and make your way across the creek and back up to the wall on the opposite side of the drainage. This route is the obvious blunted arete when you get to the top of the trail, and the left most of the three bolted lines.

content.description:
Slightly overhanging route with two distinct cruxes.

A few technical moves on a slab gains a ledge below the steeper wall above.  A quick thin move off the ledge leads to deep pockets at the third bolt and the first crux- a big move off a shallow two-finger pocket.  Better pockets follow, but tricky reach to a shallow two-finger pocket looms above.  Past this the holds improve dramatically to the chains.

Since it ends below a big roof this routes tends to stay dry in rain.  Gets lots of morning sun.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bold anchor.
content.location: Right of Golden Snow Cone.

content.description: Climb thin slab to a ledge. Pull off the ledge on crimps and follow through small pockets up the face until the walls switch to a slightly overhung finish.
content.location: Follow the trail right from the first gold wall until it meets up with the cliff where a large flake is just before the arch. This climb goes up the slab just right of the flake (Don't Do It, 5.2 Trad).

content.description: Start with a couple of long moves on good holds on orange rock and move up and left into a dihedral.  Continue 5.9 climbing up and left until the midway point where you begin to trend right.  After clipping the last bolt traverse right under and past the chains and pull a harder move to holds from which to clip.
content.location: This is the last route on the North side before the manky cave with the waterfall that feeds the head of the Bald Rock Fork creek at the end of the Holler.

content.description: A classic route with boulder problems separated by rests.
content.location: On the left side of the cave. Between All That Twitters and Squirrels Gone Wild.

content.description:
Start off a boulder and find a way to establish yourself on the left facing corner.  Moderate climbing leads to a sit down rest and the upper half of the route.  Progressively harder climbing up steepening rock leads to a series of pinches and good edges before a few longer moves to holds below the chains.  Save some energy for the anchor clip.

High quality rock once leaving the initial ledge midway.
content.location: Located in the big amphitheater on the right side, about 5 min walk past the trail break from the lode.  This route is the 2nd from the right and is distinguished by a small hanging left facing corner for the first two bolts.

content.description: Start on a lower angle section up to a stance.  Continue up on continuous pumpy climbing with a few small holds, and a few cruxy sections.
content.location: Middle route of three on this section in The Bear's Den.  To the left is "Low Hanging Fruit" to the right is "Clay City Exit"

content.description: Starts behind a tree and wanders up pocket moves over a low roof to a tricky finger crack.
content.location: Just to the right as the trail meets the cliff. Starts around a boulder at the base of the cliff.

content.description: This entertaining and atypical red route climbs the beautiful arete on the left side of the Gold Wall.  After Stickclipping the first bolt, make difficult moves to get established on the overhung face.  Pull past several bolts to get established on the slab.  Creep up the enjoyable slab that has just enough holds to keep it fun, to the anchors just above a ledge as the wall turns to an overhang.
content.location: At the Gold Wall portion of the Southeast facing side of Bear's Den.  Take the second spur trail to approach this.  This climbs the obvious arete.  To the left is "Wet Willy" a 5.10a trad route, to the Right is "Zero Dark Fiddy" a 5.13a sport route.

content.description: Climb easily off the ground utilizing a nice left facing flake.  After establishing on the wall a few big pulls between pockets leads to a lower angle face above.  The face has just enough holds to keep it reasonable and not too thin.
content.location: Far right side of "Gold Wall", starts behind a boulder.  To the left is "Barren Gold" a 5.11d

climbs.name: Mooch
climbs.fa: Mike Anderson, Janelle Anderson, and Shaun Corpron in 2010

content.description:
Long and pumpy with marginal rock in spots.

Start with a fingery boulder problem or a dihehral crack.  Tough sequences between very good rests and ledges to a crux at 3/4 height and more endurance climbing to the chains.

Will get at least another star when it cleans up.  Stays in the shade until late morning.  Top gets wet in heavy rain.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor
content.location: The rightmost route in the steep amphitheater.

content.description:
A nice fingery route with lots of crisp, fragile edges.

Easy moves up a slab lead to a layback section below the steeper upper half.  Crimp and wander up the slightly overhanging wall and then cut hard left to avoid the crack and do a few harder moves just below the anchors.

The hardest part of this route is choosing which way to go and finding the best holds.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Left of Psychopomp. Obvious crack at the top.

content.description: Start with a few slopey holds and climb through left-trending mostly moderate terrain to a rest. Make a few tough moves before taking on the cruxy finish and anchor clip.
content.location: The leftmost climb on the Twelve Wall, just left of the popular route Bear Belly.

content.description: This route climbs up to a shallow hueco about 2/3 of the way up the route and finishes in dark colored slabby rock with water groves that is often wet from water runoff.
content.location: This route is at the far end of the North side of the hollar on the slab wall, look for the obvious large (but shallow) hueco higher up on the route.

content.description:
You turn the corner at the Den and see a quiet cave. A striking right facing corner in there looks like it holds a zillion knee bars. It does! But they're not useful.

Stick clip one and crawl up on a ledge and grab a great hold. Boulder to the arete and make a bunch of funky moves in the dihedral before a really sick move to clip the chains.
content.location: right after the 3rd streak in the the cave. Look for a right facing arete.

content.description: Climb the large left leaning right facing flake to perfect pockets on the face above.
content.location: On the left side of a pocketed face that is to the right of a slab to overhung wall.

content.description: Good average 5.8 climb.  Sustained, but no defined crux.
content.location:
See

redriverclimbing.com/RRCGui…

content.description: Lieback the wide crack up the fat flake trying not to rip the whole thing off, it's just a wee bit hollow...
content.location: On the left side of the small amphitheater left of the gold/lichen wall.

content.description: Continue onto the face above the wide flake. Long moves on thin holds above the roof bring you to the chains.
content.location: Climbs the bolted face above the large flake of "Don't Do It"

content.description: The overhanging crack system right of the short sport lines. Cool face holds and a few jams lead to a spicy water groove with great rock and just enough pro in horizontals.
content.location: Right off Clay City Exit in the little overhanging alcove

content.description:
A very fun route with a steep start, an easy middle and a crux at the top.

Follow big jugs and cool pinches out a bulge to a no-hands rest about 15 feet up.  A couple of easy moves lead to another no-hands in a concave.  Then punch it through the headwall to a single hard move below the anchors.

This is the best warmup on this side of the Den.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of Psychopomp.  The furthest right sport route on this section of the wall.

content.description: Nondescript climbing on mostly good, but unchalked, holds. A true classic.
content.protection: 7 bolts (with 2 fixed draws) to bolted anchor
content.location: To the right of Gandee Candy, there is a ledge that overlooks the steep wall to the right. There are 4 climbs on this ledge - Cindy Groms is second from the left.

content.description: Work you way up onto a ledge and then climb up crimps to the top.
content.location: It is the bolted line directly to the left of Low Hanging Fruit.

content.description: Start on the left-facing flake / ramp feature and climb moderate terrain to the bolt before the break in the wall. Do some aggressive standing to gain the jugs at the break and take on the tough pockets above to get to the chains.
content.location: Second route from the left on the Twelve Wall, between Loaded for Bear and Ticks and Beer. This route starts on a left-facing flake / ramp feature.

content.description: Low angle route with a crux in the middle.  Scramble up easy rock, pull over a small roof and power through some small pockets and slopers to a nice finish on good edges and pockets. This route tends to dry quickly because it doesn't get much runoff. It gets morning sun.
content.protection: 9 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: First route right of the large amphitheater.

content.description: One of the best at the wall. Interesting moves the whole way, tough holds at the top.
content.location: A few routes right of the second trail up to Gold Wall

content.description:
A long and very pumpy route with a vertical start, a steep headwall and a topout crux.

Meander past bright yellow patches of lichen to a no hands rest on a ledge about 25 feet up.  Work up the flake, and cast into a long section of perfect pockets and edges with the occasional shake.  Save some energy for the unique lip encounter at the very top!

To avoid rope drag you may want to down climb from the chains and lower off the last draw.

Gets lots of morning sun.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.  60 meter rope will get you down.
content.location: Left of Golden Snow Cone.
